bdy.p:
World Financial Group (WFG) is a financial services organization based in
Duluth, Georgia that markets investment, insurance and mortgage products through a network of associates in the
United States
and
Canada . WFG is a wholly owned subsidiary of The AEGON Group.1

WFG's insurance and mortgage lines of business are managed directly by WFG in the United States, while its investment lines of business are managed by its affiliate broker-dealer World Group Securities, Inc.

In Canada, WFG's insurance lines of business are managed by its provincially regulated subsidiary managing general agent World Financial Group Insurance Agency of Canada Inc.; while its investment lines of business are managed by its subsidiary WFG Securities of Canada, Inc., which is a member of the Investment Funds Institute of Canada and the Mutual Fund Dealers Association of Canada.2 WFG's Canadian head office is located in Vaughan, Ontario.

World Financial Group created and partnered up with Investment Advisors International (IAI), a co-owned investment advisory firm to give clients fee-based actively managed accounts by third-party money managers. IAI has agreements with some of the nation's top investment advisory firms such as Hanlon Investments, Foxhall Capital Management, Curian Capital, CLS Investment Firm, LLC, Flexible Plan Investments, Ltd. and The Institute for Wealth Management.

sec.p: World Financial Group was formed in 2001 from the select purchase of assets by AEGON from the now defunct World Marketing Alliance (WMA). The former company was founded in 1991 by Hubert Humphrey, who subsequently founded World Leadership Group.
The Toronto-based WFG was named Canada's best MGA and top firm overall in 2006 and 2007 surveys conducted by Investment Executive, a newspaper for Canadian financial advisors3 4

In
NASCAR , World Financial Group is a major sponsor of
Roush Fenway Racing
, sponsoring
Carl Edwards 's ride part-time on the #60 Ford in the Busch Series. Previously, WFG had sponsored Roush Racing on Edwards' #99 Ford in the NEXTEL Cup Series and the #50 Ford in the
Craftsman Truck Series . 5

In 2007 WFG signed a two-year sponsorship agreement with Fox Sports Network and the Pacific Ten Conference (Pac-10). The Pac-10 - known as the "Conference of Champions" - is a NCAA Division 1 college athletic conference that includes 10 of the biggest schools on the West Coast. 6

On Wednesday, Oct. 3, 2007, WFG agreed to a three-year sponsorship of USA Luge. With the sponsorship WFG will support the athletes and programs of USA Luge as they take part in major competitions around the globe. 7

WFG's stated mission goal is to "serve the financial needs of individuals and families typically overlooked by the financial services industry".8 It is yet unclear how successfully the company has managed to distance itself from its more controversial predecessor, associated with fraud, misrepresentation and false statements, and the subject of class action lawsuits, and NASD disciplinary action.910

An April 2008 Bloomberg article also reports on recent accusations by securities regulators in Missouri, Utah, as well as others, aimed at WFG for "misrepresenting investment returns and making unsuitable sales of variable annuities". There have also been cases of private arbitrations "where variable annuities were allegedly sold to people too old to realize any benefit before they died" 11.

As well, the 'multigenerational',12 and recursive associate-recruiting based compensation13 business model that WFG follows in Canada places it firmly under classification as a "multi-level-marketing-plan" of business, as classified by the Canadian Competition Act, Section 55 and 55.1,14 and any company representative operating in Canada is subject to regulation under such classification. An annual and transition report filed for the parent corporation AEGON, with the SEC also classifies WFG as a "multi-level-marketing group of wealth management advisor networks".15

Further, "Establishing a tradition that lives on at World Financial, Humphrey (the founder) staged lavish conventions and handed out an assortment of diamond-studded rings and other luxuries to motivate the troops.16
